'''Chris Rush''' is an American comedian, writer, actor, radio personality and author. He is best known for his stand-up routines and albums, along with having been a writer and editor on the [[satirical]] publication [[National Lampoon (magazine)|''National Lampoon'' magazine]].<ref name=LH-L>{{cite news|title=Lampooner in town|last=|first=|date=October 29, 2004|publisher=''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]''|page=3|accessdate=November 18, 2009}}</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life=== Rush was born in [[Brooklyn]], New York.<ref name="youtube.com">{{YouTube|wQGoFM-d-qU|clip}}</ref> Rush is of Italian descent and was raised in the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] faith.<ref name="youtube.com"/><ref>{{YouTube|0iN-GRTCPXU|Second clip}}</ref> He attended [[Brooklyn Technical High School]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2014}} and graduated from [[City College of New York]] in 1968 with a degree in [[Organic chemistry]].<ref name=TMC>{{cite news|title=Microscope guy' is standing up to scrutiny|last=Righi|first=Len|date=May 10, 1991|publisher=''[[The Morning Call]]''|page=D.02|accessdate=November 14, 2009}}</ref> Before becoming a comedian Rush was a [[Molecular biology|molecular biologist]], working at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital for two years.<ref name=TMC /> He embarked on a professional comedy career following an [[open mic]] night at a [[comedy club]].<ref name="natural-humor-medicine.com">[http://www.natural-humor-medicine.com/Chris_Rush.html Natural Humor Medicine: Chris Rush] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041121000000/http://www.natural-humor-medicine.com/Chris_Rush.html |date=November 21, 2004 }}</ref>
===Personal life=== Rush is a conservationist and supporter of [[Greenpeace]].<ref name=Record>{{cite news|title=Spirituality with a smile|last=Solimine|first=Donna|date= July 25, 1997|publisher=''[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Record]]''|page=31|accessdate=November 6, 2009}}</ref> Though raised in the [[Catholicism|Catholic]] faith he left the church when in the seventh grade.<ref name="youtube.com"/> He considers himself to be a [[Taoism|Taoist]] and can be seen wearing the [[Yin and yang]] symbol on his shirt during his performances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myspace.com/chrisrushcomedy|title=Chris Rush (chrisrushcomedy) on Myspace|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref>
==Career==
===1970s & 1980s=== Chris Rush wrote for ''[[National Lampoon (magazine)|National Lampoon Magazine]]'' in the early 1970s,<ref name=Record /> making his first appearance in the August, 1970 issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksverylarge.com/issues/7008.html|title=National Lampoon Issue #5 - Paranoia|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref> During his time at the Lampoon he was involved in another comedy magazine titled ''Drool'', which came out with just one issue in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sirrealcomix.mrainey.com/page/d/Drool01-1.htm|title=Drool #1|first=Sir|last=Real|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref> He left the magazine when he was signed to [[Atlantic Records]] by [[Ahmet Ertegun]] to release his first comedy album, ''First Rush'' in 1973.<ref>[http://www.wamcarts.org/artsched.html Wamcarts.org] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091204153734/http://www.wamcarts.org/artsched.html |date=December 4, 2009 }}</ref> In 1974 he once again contributed to a comedy magazine titled ''Harpoon''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gusbooks.com/?page=shop/flypage&product_id=26890&CLSN_2380=13082873752380b769ad4fa179da72b0|title=HARPOON, September 1974|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref> Towards the later years of the 1970s; Rush, was involved with ''Head Magazine''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calibanbooks.com/pages/books/z08733/charlotte-faye-greenberg-mike-colasuonno-chris-rush-alan-earle/six-issues-of-head-magazine-from-1976-1978|title=Six Issues of Head Magazine from 1976-1978 by Charlotte Faye Greenberg, Mike Colasuonno Chris Rush, Alan on Caliban Books|first=|last=www.bibliopolis.com|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref>
Rush opened for musicians and bands including [[B.B. King]], [[Meat Loaf]], [[Talking Heads]], [[Twisted Sister]] and [[Electric Light Orchestra]] while becoming a frequent performer at [[comedy clubs]], theaters and [[colleges]] throughout the United States and Canada. He performed at such venues as [[The Bottom Line (venue)|The Bottom Line]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bottomlinecabaret.com/archive_index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020806115102/http://bottomlinecabaret.com/archive_index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 6, 2002 |title=Welcome To The Bottom Line Nightclub |publisher= |accessdate=July 19, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[Caroline's]], [[The Improv]] and [[The Comedy Store (California)|The Comedy Store]].<ref>{{cite news|title=New York Comedian Rush A Pearl|last=|first=|date=September 19, 1987|publisher=''[[The News Journal]]''|page=2E|accessdate=December 30, 2009}}</ref> In 1979 he was awarded "Best Male Comic" by the Association of Comedy Artists.<ref>{{cite news|title='Ribald' N.Y. comic set for Monday night|last=|first=|date=November 8, 1984|publisher=''[[The Register-Guard|Eugene Register-Guard]]''|page=2D|accessdate=December 8, 2014}}</ref> He released his second album ''Beaming In'' in 1981. His performances landed him on national television with appearances on ''Comedy Tonight,'' [[Night Flight (TV series)|Night Flight]] and ''Apt. 2C'', a pilot for [[HBO]] starring his [[mentor]] and [[friend]] [[George Carlin]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Comedic Anniversary|date=June 23, 1989|publisher=''[[The Post-Standard]]''|accessdate=November 6, 2009}}</ref>
===1990s & 2000s=== In the early to mid-1990s, Rush was involved in a series of shorts made for [[Comedy Central|Comedy Central's]] show ''Small Doses'', titled ''Food for Thought''. It starred [[Patton Oswalt]] and [[Blaine Capatch]] as two bumbling store clerks and Chris as the manager.<ref>{{YouTube|pg6R1-96w3o|Third Clip}}</ref> He was asked to contribute to [[Tim Allen|Tim Allen's]] book ''I'm Not Really Here'', which was released in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HEoe9MWqGwoC|title=I'm Not Really Here|first=Tim|last=Allen|date=November 18, 1996|publisher=Hyperion|accessdate=July 19, 2016|via=Google Books}}</ref> He released an additional comedy album in 1997. During this time, he made sporadic stand-up comedy appearances. He worked on Bob "Wolf" Wohlfeld's show in the late 1990s on [[PYX 106]] with ''The Wakin' Up with the Wolf Show'', where he was a co-host. Some of his bits were put onto an album released by the show, titled ''Chris's Head.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madhousestudios.com/graphic/pyx106/cd/chrishead.html|title=Chris's Head CD|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref> The relationship ended though when the station decided to fire Rush on December 21, 1998, after apparently speaking to management about Wohlfeld's behavior towards him and others.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wolf loses yet another sidekick|last=McGuire|first=Mark|date=April 7, 1999|publisher=''[[Times Union (Albany)|The Times Union]]''|page=D5|accessdate=November 6, 2009}}</ref>
On October 1, 2007, Rush released his first book, ''Milking the Rhino (Dangerously Funny Lists)''.
In April, 2009 Chris launched a [[one-person show|one-man show]] titled, ''Bliss: An Evening of Laughter with Chris Rush'', which was financed by George Carlin before he died in June, 2008.<ref>[http://www.theatermania.com/new-york/shows/bliss-an-evening-of-laughter-with-chris-rush_154317/ Theatermania.com: Bliss: An Evening of Laughter with Chris Rush'']</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Seven Dirty Words: The Life and Crimes of George Carlin|author=Sullivan, James|publisher=''[[Da Capo Press]]''|page=224|year=2010|isbn=0-306-81829-9}}</ref>

===Radio=== In addition to being a co-host on PYX 106, Rush has been an often guest on ''The [[Joey Reynolds]] Show'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chrisrushcomedy.com/|title=ブラックリストキャッシングの秘密／お金を借りる為の知識と注意点|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.wor710.com/pages/46264 WOR710.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090502212341/http://www.wor710.com/pages/46264 |date=May 2, 2009 }}</ref> ''The [[Morning Zoo]] on [[WMMR]], ''Esoterica with Johnny Rizzo'' on [[WPKN]], where he does a once a month call in segment talking about recent events,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.wpkn.org/show/profile/140|title=WPKN Archives:|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref> [[Dr. Demento]], who will sometimes play Chris' comedy routines<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dmdb.org/cgi-bin/search_pl.pl?string=Chris%20Rush&searchtype=either&matchtype=and&wordtype=substring&expanded=type&year1=1970&year2=current&sort=newest%20first&pltype=synd&saved=yes|title=Search Results for "Chris Rush", search type 'either', match type 'and', word type 'substring'; from 1970 to 2016, sorting newest first, playlist type(s) synd|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref> and he's also appeared on [[Opie and Anthony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiosanthony.com/Rundowns/2005/January/Week%2015/01.11.05.htm|title=Rundown for Tuesday|publisher=|accessdate=July 19, 2016}}</ref>
